BE

ISAT is currently migrating XpressLink customers into GX and has indicated an ARPU of c. USD3,400 per ship per month i.e. revenues of c. USD100m. However we would not expect such an ARPU for either the Marlink or SpeedCast contracts: 1. The Marlink and SpeedCast contracts are wholesale deal, we believe, whilst the migration from XpressLink to GX is retail: there is therefore probably a c. 20-25% mark up on retail vs wholesale. 2. The Marlink contract is a 'pay or take' contract on a large volume so there is probably a large discount to ordinary wholesale prices. We suspect the SpeedCast contract is similar 3. Prices are expected to come down in the industry over 5Y given the large supply coming to market from many players (see our report European Satellite Services: HTS: Barbarians at the Gate) which would likely be incorporated in this contract. Putting all this together we believe an ARPU of between USD1,000-USD1500 is credible. This would represent USD60-90m of revenues by Year 5, i.e. between 12% to 18% of the 5Y revenue target for GX. So clearly a re-assuring data point but not enough to change our view that the USD500m target for GX by Year 5 of commercial launch (2020) is too high and that part of the GX growth comes at the expense of legacy revenues. We are UW.

11:24 am
BE

While on the sector, which we are sort of ...........

BE

Not going to try and navigate around the O2 buyout reports, because it's Monday and I've had better things to do than read them.

BE

However, there's a sector piece out of Macquarie on Liberty and Vodafone which is worth a look.

11:25 am
BE

Positive on the former, negative on the latter.

BE

The big strategy approach is in the Liberty side, so that's where I'll begin.

BE

Starting July 1st, Liberty Global will jettison LiLAC and by year-end, Ziggo. What's
next? Dividing the house frees up financial and operational capacity to take
advantage of the current regulatory/M&A backdrop in the UK. Multiple scenarios
could benefit Liberty Global and present upside to our US$50 target. Our EU
Telecom Analyst G. Peddy's downgrade of Vodafone highlights Virgin’s structural
advantage. Separately, though Brexit is on investors' minds, we think the impact is
minimal. Virgin Media comprises ~41%/~38%~8% of revenue, OCF, and debt;
forward contracts and other derivatives are in place to hedge sterling exposure.

11:26 am
BE

Impact
Uncertainty around the £10.3bn deal between ThreeUK and Telefonica O2 as well
as regulatory oversight could work in favor of Virgin. The blocking of the deal
between these wireless players and the EU’s apparent comfort with cross-
technological consolidation pave the way for operators to consider alternative paths.

BE

Scenario #1: A Virgin-O2 deal
Liberty Global has expressed interest in seeking owner economics in wireless.
The structure of the Ziggo-Vodafone deal in the Netherlands could free up
capacity for Liberty Global’s M&A optionality in the UK. In addition to a €1bn
cash payment from Vodafone, leverage will remain at 4.5-5x for an incremental €2-
3bn in debt with proceeds distributed equally. We believe the agreement with Liberty
Global for a Dutch JV reinforces Vodafone’s structural challenges.
With increased financial flexibility, Liberty may opt to acquire O2. In our view,
the transaction could be ~11% EPS/FCF accretive in the first two years.

BE

Scenario #2: A Better Competitive Landscape
According to Guy Peddy, price increases could arise in the short run; neither
ThreeUK nor O2 is generating sufficient returns to continue their network
investments. ThreeUK is spectrum constrained and would need to further invest in
its network to add capacity; O2 has low-band spectrum but few high-band holdings.
Sky Mobile’s quad play offer resulting from its MVNO agreement with O2
threatens to take subs away from the large wireless carriers. However, this
could be to the benefit of smaller players like Virgin Media.

11:26 am
BE

Scenario #3: A merger/partnership with Vodafone
Liberty Global may have more concerns in the UK and Vodafone in Germany, as
they face similar structural challenges – both are sub-scale relative to competitors in
their core markets. In both markets, the incumbent’s network upgrades are
minimizing the speed advantages of the CATV operators and Vodafone has an
inferior spectrum /network plan compared to the incumbent’s wireless propositions.

BE

And on the Vodafone side .........

BE

We believe the agreement with Liberty Global for a Dutch JV reinforces
Vodafone’s structural challenges given the company is pursuing a convergent
strategy. Vodafone has to either hit the M&A button (back to LBTYA or Sky) or
continually spend more on networks via capex given it faces competition from
incumbents and challengers.

11:28 am
BE

If the UK remains in the EU, the sterling will likely strengthen. This will
depress Vodafone’s share price and reduce the value of the dividend, which
has been fixed at €14.48¢, at a relative low in € currency terms. Vodafone’s
recent outperformance has been supported by sterling weakness.
 There is limited upside to our revised target of 225p, TSR of 8%.

BE

Risks are understated
 The move to a € denominated reporting from FY16/17 reduces the dividend
visibility on the shares. We target a cut in the dividend from FY17/18 to an
effective 8p/€10.24c (consensus 11.6p). Our model assumes the long term
DPS payout at 68% of EPS and 50% of FCF (pre spectrum).
 BT Business will offer significant competition in the UK mobile market. We
expect Vodafone to defend its market share vigorously but given over 50% of
Vodafone’s UK business is enterprise/business, a £100m loss of revenue is
equivalent to 3% of domestic revenue. Sky Mobile’s launch will also increase
UK competitive tension in consumer market.
 The competitive environment in India is increasingly inflamed with the
potential launch of Jio 2H16 and compromised growth and margins in the
midterm. We expect that Jio will be a credible top-3 player in the market in 2
years (15% share in 4 years), as it seeds a data boom in India due to its
nationwide 2.3Ghz spectrum position. Spectrum costs are potentially
increasing again in India, with plans to auction 700Mhz spectrum. We target a
£1bn cost in FY16/17.
 In the long term, we believe capital intensity will be maintained at high levels
in order to sustain revenue growth and mitigate structural challenges. We now
expect future OCF growth to be lower than expected at the time of the Project
Spring announcement and our targets imply a lower midterm OCF than
expected by consensus (15% lower in FY17/18). We expect future returns to
be lower than pre-Spring at 4-5%; below cost of capital despite trading at
Book Value.

BE

The knowns are all well-known – expectations full

11:29 am
BE

Service revenue is recovering and we target 2.0% in 1Q16/17, improving to
2.3-2.7% in the coming quarters despite roaming and MVNO headwinds.
Margins can improve, especially as the handset replacement cycle continues
to expand and as Project Spring unwinds. We target 1.2pp by FY20/21. But
growth expectations are already full. Ex-headwinds and FX we target 5%
OIBDA growth in FY16/17 – consensus assumes 6%.

BE

 In the UK our preferences are for Sky (TP 1400p) and TalkTalk (TP 333p).
Among European large caps we highlight Orange (TP €18) and Telefónica
(TP €10.5) and Iliad (TP €240) and Drillisch (TP €53) among the challengers.
We also rate Liberty Global Outperform (TP $50).

Major changes are taking place at Board level of the back-office optimisation software company. Nigel Payne will be replacing Duncan McIntyre as Non-Exec Chairman, subject to a due diligence process. CFO Jonathan Kay will also be leaving, although he will remain to oversee an orderly transition. Finally, two NEDs will also be leaving. Nigel Payne has extensive experience with listed technology companies.

BE

Having said this about last week's trading update.

BE

Four months into FY 2017, a trading update has reaffirmed the management team’s FY earnings guidance - of £0.5m adj. PBT and 2.2p FD adj. EPs - but also flags up a more dramatic H2 weighting than seen last year, due to lengthy discussions ahead of the closure of some particularly large deals. While this naturally increases risk of slippage, we are reassured by management’s confidence in the positive progress on these deals and in delivering a strong H2 profit. It proved its ability to do so last year (FY 2016 swinging from an £0.3m H1 loss to a £0.4m profit in H2). At this relatively early stage, we acknowledge a concern but make no change in FY 2017 earnings forecasts and will review the situation once we have better visibility on the six months trading to July and the order book at the time of the Interims.

PM

BHP

PM

Credit suisse catching us up on the Samarco situation

PM

Samarco causes and costs: First glimpse

11:36 am
BE

Oh yeah, on the update last week. Go on.

PM

Criminal report previews external technical report due soon: Preliminary
results of the criminal investigation by Brazil Federal Police into the Samacro
dam accident lays some blame on the executives of the Samarco JV (as
reported in the WSJ). The criminal investigation in our view is a useful
potential preview of the external investigation into the technical causes of the
accident due to be released in coming weeks (schedule is for "mid-year"
release).

PM

There appears to be no suggestion of natural cause (such as a land tremor
or seismic activity) and liquefaction (water turning the earth structure to mud
over time) is firming as the key reason. Questions are asked in the report
about decisions made at time of construction with respect to the drainage
system and potential design alterations. The report suggests that the Vale
mine may have used the dam in addition to Samarco (Vale had denied
wrongdoing) and that the walls were raised higher and faster than advisable
in recent years. In our view, the incremental implications of this report are
probably limited for BHP (but not positive), and we await release of the more
detailed full investigation

11:36 am
PM

Investment case still holds: BHP's oil business is setting it apart from the
sector peer group and the company recently outlined positive FY17 cost and
volume guidance (refer: Cost guidance positive, 14-May). While a significant
and upmost serious issue, we do not think Samarco has the potential to
undermine our overall positive view of the shares at this stage. Catalysts:
External technical Samarco report due "mid-year" and by 30-June the
Foundation body to oversee restoration is to be incorporated. Q4-production
report 20-July, full year result due 16-August. Valuation at spot: 6.6x
EBITDA, FCF yield 9.9%, 1.2x ND:EBITDA and 3.1% div yield. Based on the
Framework agreement details we assume $1bn of future payments for BHP.
If BHP's costs associated with Samarco increased by say $5bn, it would
lower our valuation by ~7%, but is likely to take years to play out in our view.

BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 821.60, down 5.7 (-0.69%), High: 827.60, Low: 813.10, Volume: 2.10m
PM

Suggested causes (per WSJ article):
■ Collapse due to liquefaction (when water infiltrates an earth structure turning it to
mud).
■ How did the water get in there?
o During construction of the drainage system, alternate materials were
used other than the rock and gravel specified.
o Design alterations on the outer wall of the dam did not utilize a gully as
originally designed.
■ VALE’s nearby Alegria mine dumped waste (slimes) into the dam, in addition to the
Samarco mines dumping its waste there as planned (we note VALE have denied
wrongdoing here).
■ There is some suggestion the dam walls were raised higher and faster than
advised each year to accommodate an expansion of the mine.

11:39 am
Restaurant Group PLC (RTN:LSE): Last: 357.10, down 1.5 (-0.42%), High: 361.80, Low: 357.00, Volume: 530.85k
BE

Difficult Trading Environment

At the recent update management highlighted a further deterioration in trading in the leisure business. In this note we revisit the investment case following this recent weak trading. We update estimates in light of guidance. We retain our DCF derived price target at 350p, albeit upgrade our recommendation to Neutral largely on valuation following the recent share price weakness.

BE

Take-Out Speculation

We note recent press commentary which suggests the business may have had interest from private equity. We therefore look at the group on a SOTP basis. We suggest that the current valuation arguably looks attractive, especially when you consider the pre-expansionary cap-ex cash generation of the group at £76.1m 2016e.

11:39 am
BE

However Headwinds Remain

We remain concerned regarding the operating environment however. We undertake a comprehensive Frankie & Benny’s site analysis which suggests the business has significant competition across the estate. We note a number of other headwinds for the group including limited retail & leisure park planned space expansion, slowing consumer foodservice spend growth, weak retail lfl environment, poor brand perception, cost pressures and returns fading.

BE

Recommendation Upgrade, But Caution Continues

Whilst we raise our recommendation (to Neutral) largely on the basis of valuation, we retain an overall cautious stance at this stage. We await conclusion of the ongoing strategic review which be announced at the FY16e interim results in August.

Estimates Updated

We have revised our estimates following the recent trading update reducing our LFL growth assumptions and assuming a slower new site rollout. We cut adj EPS by -12%, -17% and -17% for FY16E, FY17E and FY18E.

Valuation and Recommendation

Our DCF based valuation remains unchanged at 350p with downward revision to our earnings offset by lower capex assumptions. At current levels the shares trade on a CY17E PE of 12.3x and adj. EV/adj. EBIT of 9.9x, with a 4.5% expected dividend yield.

BE

PM

13 June 2016
G4S is deeply shocked by the tragic events in Orlando this weekend and the thoughts of everyone at G4S are with the victims and their families.

Omar Mateen was employed by G4S at a residential community in South Florida and was off-duty at the time of the incident. Mateen was subject to detailed company screening when he was recruited in 2007 and re-screened in 2013 with no adverse findings. He was also subject to checks by a U.S. law enforcement agency with no findings reported to G4S.

G4S is providing its full support to all law enforcement authorities in the USA as they conduct their investigations.

11:53 am
BE

PM

John Wraith has raised the prospect of the UK re-starting QE

PM

The UK economy has been losing momentum
Over the past four quarters, the average pace of growth in the UK has been the slowest since the first quarter of 2013. There are signs that growth may slow further in Q2, and some members of the MPC are starting to sound increasingly anxious about the outlook. Our central case is that the UK economy will re-accelerate in the second half of 2016. But it is certainly a plausible alternative scenario that the economy could slow further in the upcoming quarters. We think that if activity does slow further beyond the end of the second quarter, the market is likely to rapidly start considering how the MPC may choose to enact any further easing deemed necessary.

Limited scope for conventional easing…
We would expect the MPC's first active intervention to take the form of a conventional easing of policy, with Bank Rate likely to be cut from 0.50% first to 0.25%, and then possibly to zero. Recent observations from senior MPC members, and the questionable success of negative rate policies in other economies, make us doubt whether such an experiment will be pursued in the UK, at least not in the first instance.

…will swiftly reignite expectations of a resumption of QE
We think it is highly likely that markets would start to factor in the possibility of a resumption of QE once Bank Rate has been cut to 0.25%, or possibly to zero. While several other options for easing monetary conditions are available to the Bank of England, large scale purchases of conventional Gilts financed by the creation of additional Central Bank reserves is by far the most likely initial response.

Lessons from previous episodes
We look back at the two earlier experiments in the UK with QE, the first conducted from March 2009-January 2010, and the second from October 2011-October 2012. We see the latter as a better guide for how markets may behave in the run-up to a future resumption, as it took place against a more similar market and economic backdrop

11:53 am
PM

Outperformance of conventional Gilts in the run-up to QE
The main trend is one of relative richening of conventional Gilts as anticipation of additional QE intensifies. With short yields so low and sub 3y debt probably ineligible once again, the curve would likely bull flatten. Gilts outperformed Eurozone sovereign debt, and we would expect them to do so again. There was also a richening on asset swap, and compression of breakevens. This last point may seem counterintuitive with QE potentially boosting inflation expectations, but the mechanical pressure exerted by the Bank of England carrying out such large purchases and limiting them toconventional debt outweighs any fundamental influences, at least for a time.

Bad for banks and for mid-caps
In this scenario, the FTSE 100 would be relatively insulated from the domestic slowdown (c.75% of revenues from overseas), but the mid-250 would be more exposed. Sectors most exposed to falling Gilt yields and that are less domestically focussed would be likely winners: Pharma, Food Producers and Tobacco. Insurance and Banks are likely underperformers. The view from a bank equity investor's perspective is clear, we think. With the exception of a cheaper, enlarged Funding for Lending scheme we would see virtually any other form of further monetary accommodation from the Bank of England as damaging to bank sector profitability and threatening the effectiveness of the monetary transmission mechanism. We would expect Bank Rate reductions or restarted government bond purchases to lead to cuts to forecast earnings as well as the valuation multiples applied to lowered EPS numbers.

12:00 pm
PM

Implied Distributions from Gbpusd Risk-Reversals and Implication for Brexit Scenarios

PM

Abstract:
Much of the debate around a potential British exit (Brexit) from the EU has centred on the potential macroeconomic impact. In this paper, we instead focus on understanding market expectations for price action around the Brexit referendum date. Extracting implied distributions from the GBPUSD option volatility surface, we estimate that the market expects a vote to leave could result in a move in GBPUSD from 1.4390 (spot reference on 10 June 2016) down to a range in 1.10 to 1.30, i.e. a 10-25% decline - very probably with highly volatile price action. In contrast, a vote to stay could result in a modest bounce in GBPUSD to around 1.47. We apply the same analysis to contrast the behaviour of the GBPUSD option market in the run-up to the Brexit vote with that during the 2014 Scottish Independence referendum, finding the potential impact of Brexit to be considerably higher.
